tit.e: Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder)
tit.cmt: タイトルなので説明訳括弧を削除しました。次行に補足しました。
tit.e: Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder)
tit.cmt: 新バージョンの用語統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 練り菓子（ねりがし）は、別名「こなし」ともいい、粉状もしくは粒状の原料と液状もしくは粘土状の原料を配合してから、外力を繰り返し加えて分布を均一化し、粘土状の塑性変型する状態に仕上げた間食用の食品類。
sen.e: Nerigashi is also referred to as "konashi", which is a snack food produced by mixing an ingredient in the form of powder or grain and an ingredient in the form of liquid or paste, applying external forces for many times to homogenize the distribution, and finishing it in a clayey state of plastic deformation.

Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder) is also referred to as 'konashi,' which is a snack food produced by mixing an ingredient in the form of powder or grain and an ingredient in the form of liquid or paste, applying external forces for many times to homogenize the distribution, and finishing it in a clayey state of plastic deformation.
sen.cmt: 説明訳括弧を補足しました。原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder) is also referred to as 'konashi,' which is a snack food produced by mixing an ingredient in the form of powder or grain and an ingredient in the form of liquid or paste, applying external forces for many times to homogenize the distribution, and finishing it in a clayey state of plastic deformation.

sen.j: 原料の性質により、成形後にそのまま食用になるものと、蒸して加熱する必要があるものに分かれる。
sen.e: Some can be eaten as they are, and others must be steamed before eating, depending on the nature of the ingredients.
Some can be eaten as they are, and others must be steamed before eating, depending on the nature of the ingredients.
Some can be eaten as they are, and others must be steamed before eating, depending on the nature of the ingredients.

sen.j: 和菓子の内、生菓子と呼ばれるものの多くは練り菓子である。
sen.e: Most of Japanese sweets called fresh (and moist) sweets are nerigashi.
Most of Japanese sweets called fresh (and moist) sweets are nerigashi.
Most of Japanese sweets called fresh (and moist) sweets are nerigashi.

sen.j: 餅も練り菓子と類似の製法で作るが、主食と考えられる事が多く、練り菓子に入れられない事も多い。
sen.e: Rice cake is produced by a similar production method, but it is often regarded as staple diet and not included in nerigashi.
Rice cake is produced by a similar production method, but it is often regarded as staple diet and not included in nerigashi.
Rice cake is produced by a similar production method, but it is often regarded as staple diet and not included in nerigashi.

sen.j: 粉末原料として、米粉、はったい粉、黄粉、砂糖など、粒状の原料としてゴマ、クルミなど、粘土状の原料としてアズキなどの餡、液状の原料として湯、茶、牛乳、おろした芋類などがよく使われる。
sen.e: Komeko (rice powder), hattaiko(flour of roasted barley), soybean flour, and sugar are often used as the powder ingredients; sesame, walnuts are often used as the grain ingredients; pastes such as red-bean jam are often used as the paste-like ingredients; and hot water, tea, milk, and grated potatoes are often used as the liquid ingredients.
sen.cmt: ウェブサイトに従って原文を修正しました。
sen.e: Komeko (rice powder), hattaiko (flour of roasted barley), soybean flour, and sugar are often used as the powder ingredients; sesame, walnuts are often used as the grain ingredients; pastes such as red-bean jam are often used as the paste-like ingredients; and hot water, tea, milk, and grated potatoes are often used as the liquid ingredients.
sen.cmt: スペースを補足しました。
sen.e: Komeko (rice powder), hattaiko (flour of roasted barley), soybean flour, and sugar are often used as the powder ingredients; sesame, walnuts are often used as the grain ingredients; pastes such as red-bean jam are often used as the paste-like ingredients; and hot water, tea, milk, and grated potatoes are often used as the liquid ingredients.

sen.cmt: 文頭のハイフン削除しました。
